Hey I need a little advice. My life has been feeling empty and directionless for a long time and I didn't know what I wanted to do with my life. I can't tell of it's following my dream or taking some obsession too far. Sorry for the long ueqstion

you could try it until you get tired of it. for me, music hit me hard at an extremely extremely young age, then if it ever went away momentarily it would always come back and hit me harder from a different angle. various things have hit me like this at different times, but music has been deeply connected to most of them. what you see me doing today is sort of a natural merging of many many different things i have been deeply obsessed with for my entire life. so if it is not that for you, the worst thing that could happen is you may simply get tired of it. no harm in checking. one time i thought i was going to suddenly learn to trade foreign currencies and make a living off of it. i never thought about doing it before, and never had any experience doing it. i tried it and lost interest after about 2 weeks. but that doesn't mean i shouldn't have tried it

Hey it's me again, felt like asking another very specific and long winded question about your mental state as it reflects the themes and ideas of you music.

The new song "long long long journey" seems to me that it is split almost in half, or maybe thirds if you squint the right way, in regards to theme. The first part is incredibly somber and quite frankly depressing, exuding the feeling of exhaustion and trying to trick yourself into going forward (maybe this is just my personal experiences with depression and feeling desperate to keep moving, but the three lines about how far you've gone and then with the " and it's a long long long long long way back" to me feels more like a reminder that you can't change your mind now. Instead of being encouraging and motivating, to me it feels daunting and frightening that now you kind of have to keep going forward since you cant go back.) 

Regardless of the first bits, the second part se ems to t ake a more positive outlook, especially with the last line with the "road" being to success. My best guess is that this song is about struggling to stay either motivated with a project or with life in general, that or it could be about depression and a kind of subliminal encouragement to those suffering that it DOES get better if you keep fighting. Those are my two best guesses. What do you think I'm mighty wurtz?

How do you find the prime factorisation of 6 digit numbers in your head?

first you check for 3s, then check for 5s, (those are easy checks) then you gotta start checking for all the other primes one by one, from 7 and working your way up. if you rule them all out in order then you only have to go as high as the square root of the number and then you can stop. you can check the primes (like 7 for example) by maniuplating the target number by multiples of 7 until it gets to something recognizably a multiple of 7. there are endless amounts of useful/easy ways to do these manipulations, and you learn more tricks the more you do it

i am more advanced than that, (i know what diminished and augmented chords mean) what i meant to ask is how numbers work within chords for example emaj11,

that's one in particular you will probably never see. but here's the basic starting examples i can give for that: C7 means C, E, G, Bb.... Cmaj7 means C, E, G, B.  ... Cmin7 means C, Eb, G, Bb.... there are some quirks here already with the system, but hopefully those examples expose them.
whats the diffdrence between that and a sus2, stuff like that.

Csus4 means C, F, G. and Csus2 means C, D, G... so 'sus' is just a little trick that swaps the 3 out for a 4 or 2. if it doesn't say 4 or 2 then it means 4. so if you see "Csus" on paper that's gonna mean Csus4.

Can you give me a short explanation of 7th chords and diminished/aug chords? i learned to use major/minor/flat/sharp chords while playing pop but jazzy stuff has some unfamiliar chords. im trying to play what you wont do for love right now and its got c#7#9 like what does that even mean

the way that type of song uses the notation system is a bit oblique .... very normal but not a good starting point for learning chord symbols. i can tell you what chord goes there in that song, it's C# in the bass, and you're gonna want B, F, and E in the mid range. but it may not be clear how we get that from the C#7#9 chord symbol. to get the chord symbol thing a bit better, i think you should start in the key of C, and for your first example just play C major chord (the chord symbol for that is just C), and then add a Bb note to it. that is C7. that's just what that is. good starting place ...... when i was young, someone confided in me that C7 is the perfect way to signal you're about to go to the F chord. try it ... try a song in C, and play some things in the key of C and then drop that C7 and bam, the whole world knows it's time to go to F now. i think that's a good starting point ... that's where i started ... i'll never forget when i learned that. changed my life. i still use that principle in almost every song

i'm confused about songs that have that little half-step passing chord thingy (i know, i know, use your ears.. but this thing always confuses me and I hear it a lot, and I'm sure it's a really simple concept)... like that bruno mars finesse song with the C# to C7 to Fmin (i think), would that be in Fmin and the C# is a sharp 5? if somebody put those chords in front of you and told you to take a solo, what might you play over that C# chord?

that would be Dbmaj7, Caug7, Fmin9(11). honestly in that situation, over the Dbmaj7, Fmin pentatonic will be all you need. during the Caug7, honestly Bb will be your strongest note. still firmly think of F min but i guess don't really hang on the F note, technically you'd want the E note instead but don't hang on that either. and during the Fmin9(11) you'll probably have strong emphasis on those G and Bb notes and also Fmin. basically the whole time just consider Fmin pent stuff to be your home and the Bb note is gonna be really strong everywhere except the Dbmaj7 in which Ab and C (and F) will be stronger. this is all stuff you can find by just playing in F min and listening to which notes sound stronger when

If you wanna learn that stuff, task yourself with making an entire presentation of your own, in your wildest specifications, not under anyone's direction, where you are supposed to explain all that stuff. then you'll have to just go out and learn what you need somehow. you'll learn it very very well that way. but if you wanna pass someone else's test then i wouldn't know what to tell you ...maybe find their answer key?

Hey Bill, I'm the guy who had the problem with learning reading sheet music and playing piano at the same time. Just checking in to say your advice really helped as I am getting much more familiar with it as an instrument first. follow up question, when you are absolutely ripping the keyboard solo in la de da, what are those two semi wheels that seem to make it sound as if you are bending the notes on a guitar?

pitch bend, and the other one. most keyboards have those 2 wheels. the pitch bend wheel is spring loaded and usually gives you a whole step either way (or you can set it different if u want) and the other wheel is not spring loaded, and does different things depending on the instrument but on many instruments it's vibrato. i mostly use it for vibrato, on that particular sound i have it for vibrato. but on many sounds i use it for filter cutoff ("wawa"). very useful, especially in getting your digital instrument to sound a bit more like something 'real'
